page.title: 5.9.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will study exponential functions and their graphs in context. Given a graph or a description of a relationship, you write one quantity as a function of another and then use the function to answer questions about the context. You will also produce graphs of exponential functions, paying close attention to the appropriate domain and range.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Analyze a situation and determine whether it makes sense to connect the points on the graph that represents the situation.
  • Describe the relationship in a graph of an exponential function using function notation.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 5.9.1: Evaluating Expressions for Different Values of \(x\)
  • 5.9.2: Analyze Underlying Relationship in a Graph of a Function 
    • 5.9.2: Self Check 
  • 5.9.3: Graph Equations to Solve Problems
    • 5.9.3: Self Check 
  • 5.9.4: Deciding on Graphing Window 
  • 5.9.5: Interpret Graphs to Find Approximate Values

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 5.9.6: Practice
  • 5.9.7: Lesson Summary

page.title: 5.9.1: Evaluating Expressions for Different Values of x
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Lin and Diego are discussing two expressions: \(x^2\) and \(2^x\).

Lin says, “I think the two expressions are equivalent.”

Diego says, “I think the two expressions are only equal for some values of \(x\).”

Do you agree with either of them? Explain or show your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Your answer may vary, but here is an example:

I agree with Diego. Sample explanation: If we find the value of \(x^2\) and \(2^x\) for different values of \(x\), say 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4, we can see that they are not always equal. As the table shows, they are only equal sometimes, for example, when \(x\) is 2 and 4.

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(2^x\)

1

1

2

2

4

4

3

9

8

4

16

16

5

25

32

10

100

1,024

page.title: 5.9.2: Analyze Underlying Relationship in a Graph of a Function
page.contents:
Activity

The cost, in dollars, to produce 1 watt of solar energy is a function of the number of years since 1977, \(t\).

From 1977 to 1987, the cost could be modeled by an exponential function \(f\). Here is the graph of the function.


  1. What is the statement \(f(9) \approx 6\) saying about this situation?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

9 years after 1977 (or in 1986), the cost in dollars for one watt of solar energy was about $6.



  1. What is \(f(4)\)? What about \(f(3.5)\)? What do these values represent in this context?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(f(4) \approx 25\), and \(f(3.5) \approx 30\). These values represent the cost in dollars of 1 watt of solar energy in 1981 (4 years after 1977) and halfway through 1980 (3.5 years after 1977).



  1. When \(f(t)=45\), what is \(t\)? What does that value of \(t\) represent in this context?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

2 years after 1977 (in 1979), the cost in dollars of 1 watt of solar energy was $45.



  1. By what factor did the cost of 1 watt of solar energy change each year? (If you get stuck, consider creating a table.)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(\frac34\) or 0.75


Video: Understanding Characteristics of Graphs

Watch the following video to learn more about the characteristics of graphs: 



An imaginary line that a function value will not touch or cross is called an asymptote.

The value of the range that the function will never touch is called the horizontal asymptote.

In the function graphed, the horizontal asymptote is \(y=0\).

page.title: 5.9.2: Self Check
page.contents: The graph below shows the total smartphones, \(s\), in millions that were sold in the years, \(t\), since 2008. What does the point \((4, 125)\) represent in this context?

answer.answer_text: In 2004, there were 125 million smartphones sold.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: When \(t=4\), this means 4 years after 2008. The answer is in 2012, there were 125 million smartphones sold.

answer.answer_text: In 2012, there were 125 million more smartphones than in 2008.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The \(s\) value represents the total number sold, not a comparison. The answer is in 2012, there were 125 million smartphones sold.

answer.answer_text: In 2012, there were 125 million smartphones sold.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: Since \(t=4\), the point represents 2012, 4 years after 2008. The \(s\) value is 125 and represents the number of millions of smartphones sold.

answer.answer_text: In 2004, there were 125 million more smartphones than in 2000.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: When \(t=4\), this means 4 years after 2008.  The answer is in 2012, there were 125 million smartphones sold.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 5.9.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Reading Exponential Graphs

The graph below describes the amount of caffeine, \(c\), in a person’s body \(t\) hours after an initial measurement of 100 mg.

What does the point \(c(10)=35\) mean?

After 10 hours, there is 35 mg of caffeine in a person’s body.

What is the value of \(t\) when \(c(t)=80\)?

When the caffeine concentration is 80 mg, time is 2 hours, so \(t=2\).

Try It: Reading Exponential Graphs

Using the graph above, what is the value of \(c(5)\), and what does it mean in the context of the situation?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

Here is how to interpret this exponential graph:

When \(t=5\), the curve crosses at 60, so \(c(5)=60\).

This means that after 5 hours, the person has 60 mg of caffeine in their body.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.9.3: Graph Equations to Solve Problems
page.contents:
Activity

  1. The thickness \(t\) in millimeters of a folded sheet of paper after it is folded \(n\) times is given by the equation \(t=(0.05) \cdot 2^n\).

  1. What does the number 0.05 represent in the equation?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The sheet of paper is 0.05 mm thick.



  1. Use graphing technology to graph the equation \(t=(0.05) \cdot 2^n\).

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Here is a table of values for the thickness of the paper after different numbers of folds:

\(n\)

\(t\)

0

0.05

1

0.1

2

0.2

3

0.4

4

0.8

5

1.6



  1. How many folds does it take before the folded sheet of paper is more than 1 mm thick? How many folds before it is more than 1 cm thick? Explain how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

It takes 5 folds before the paper is more than 1 mm thick. After 4 folds, the paper is 0.8 mm thick, and after 5 folds, it is 1.6 mm thick. It takes 8 folds before the paper is more than 1 cm or 10 mm thick (1.28 cm to be precise).


  1. The area of a sheet of paper is 93.5 square inches.

  1. Find the remaining visible area of the sheet of paper after it is folded in half once, twice, and three times.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

46.75, 23.375, 11.6875 square inches



  1. Write an equation expressing the visible area \(a\) of the sheet of paper in terms of the number of times it has been folded, \(n\).

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\( a=93.5 \cdot (\frac{1}{2})^n\)



  1. Use graphing technology to graph the equation.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:



  1. In this context, can \(n\) take negative values? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The variable \(n\) cannot take negative values (unless the original sheet of paper can be unfolded).



  1. Can \(a\) take negative values? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No. The area of the sheet of paper can never be negative, no matter how many times it is folded.



  1. Identify the domain of the graph using an inequality.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(n \geq 0\)



  1. Identify the range of the graph using an inequality. 

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(0<a \leq 93.5\). Note that the area cannot be negative, or even 0, because the paper will not disappear.



  1. What equation represents the horizontal asymptote?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(y=0\)

page.title: 5.9.3: Self Check
page.contents:
The graph below represents the function that gives the value of a computer in dollars, \(y\), as a function of time, \(x\), measured in years since the time of purchase. 

What is the range for this graph and situation?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The range in this situation cannot be negative because the computer value will not ever be negative. The answer is \(0<y \leq400\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the domain. The answer is \(0<y \leq400\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: The largest \(y\)-value is the starting price of the computer, $400, and the lowest value will approach 0 but never actually equal $0.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The value of the computer will not go above the starting value of $400. The value of the computer will get close to zero, but it will never reach 0. The answer is \(90<y \leq400\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 5.9.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Domain and Range of Exponential Graphs

The graph below describes the amount of caffeine, \(c\), in a person’s body \(t\) hours after an initial measurement of 100 mg.

What is the smallest value \(c\) can reach?

Since \(c\) is the amount of caffeine, it can get close to 0.

Can \(t\) ever take on negative values?

No, time will not be negative in this relationship because time is moving forward.

What are the lowest and highest values for \(t\)?

At the beginning, \(t=0\), and \(t\) can go as long as it takes for \(c\) to get so close to 0 it is insignificant.

The domain (or values of \(t\)) written as an inequality is \(t \geq 0\).

The range (or values of \(c\)) written as an inequality is \(0<c \leq 100\).

Try It: Domain and Range of Exponential Graphs


The dollar value of a car is a function, \(f\), of the number of years, \(t\), since the car was purchased. The car was purchased at $12,000. Tell the domain and range.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

Here is how to determine the domain and range of an exponential function:

To determine the domain, look at the \(t\) values. The car is bought when \(t=0\), so the domain is \(t \geq 0\).

To determine the range, look at the \(f\) values, or the possible dollar values of the car. The car is bought at $12,000 and will lose value until the value is close to $0, but it will never be worth negative dollars.

The range is \(0<f \leq 12000\).

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.9.4: Deciding on Graphing Window
page.contents:
Optional Activity

The equation \(m=20 \cdot (0.8)^h\) models the amount of medicine \(m\) (in milligrams) in a patient’s body as a function of hours, \(h\), after injection.


  1. Without using a graphing tool, decide if the following horizontal and vertical boundaries are suitable for graphing this function. 

    Explain your reasoning.
    \(-10<h<100\)
    \( -100<m<1,000\)

Enter your answer here:

Your answers may vary, but here is an example:

No; Sample responses: There is probably no medicine left in the body 100 hours after injection, so it is not helpful to graph all the way to an \(h\) value of 100. And if there was any medicine in the body before injection, it wouldn’t be accounted for by this equation, so \(h\) should probably start at 0. The scale for the vertical axis is also unreasonable. The medicine is decreasing in amount, starting from 20 milligrams, so 1,000 for the upper end of the axis is far too large. The negative values for \(m\) are also not needed because a negative amount of medicine would not make any sense here.



  1. Verify your answer by graphing the equation using graphing technology and using the given graphing window. What do you see? Sketch or describe the graph.

Enter your answer here:

Your answers may vary, but here is an example:



  1. If your graph in the previous question is unhelpful, modify the window settings so that the graph is more useful. Record the window settings here. Convince a partner why the horizontal and vertical boundaries that you set are better.

Enter your answer here:

Your answers may vary, but here is an example:

A reasonable graph would have an \(h\)-axis that shows values from 0 to around 20 and an \(m\)-axis showing values from 0 to somewhere in the low 20s. Here is an example:

Points plotted on the coordinate plane, showing exponential decay. Horizontal axis from 0 to 22.5, labeled \(h\). Vertical axis from 0 to 22.5, labeled \(m\).

page.title: 5.9.5: Interpret Graphs to Find Approximate Values
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

The graph shows the bacteria population on a petri dish as a function \(f\) of the days \(d\) since an antibiotic is introduced.


  1. What is the approximate value of \(f(4.5)\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The exact value is 622,431, but reasonable approximations should be greater than 600,000 and less than 650,000.



  1. Approximately what is \(d\) when \(f(d)=400,000\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The value to one decimal place is 8.7, but reasonable approximations should be greater than 8.5 and less than 9.


  1. Explain what you would do, using your usual graphing technology, to be able to see \(f(15)\) on the graph.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

You may change xmax to 17, keeping all other window settings.

Discuss your explanation with a partner.

page.title: 5.9.6: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. The number of people with the flu during an epidemic is a function, \(f\), of the number of days, \(d\), since the epidemic began. The equation \(f(d)=50 \cdot (\frac{3}{2})^d\) defines \(f\).

    1. How many people had the flu at the beginning of the epidemic? Insert integers only.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 50 because \(f(0)=50\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What does \(f(1)\) mean in this situation?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The number of people infected 1 day after the epidemic began. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The function, \(f\), gives the dollar value of a bond \(t\) years after the bond was purchased. The graph of \(f\) is shown.

    1. What is \(f(0)\)? Insert integers only. No commas or spaces.

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.9.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 1000. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. When is \(f(t)=1500\)? Estimate the nearest whole number. Insert integers only.

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.9.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 8. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A function \(f\) gives the number of stray cats in a town \(t\) years since the town started an animal control program. The program includes both sterilizing stray cats and finding homes to adopt them. An equation representing \(f\) is \(f(t)=243{(\frac13)}^t\).

    1. What is the value of \(f(t)\) when \(t\) is 0? Enter integers only.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 5.9.2–5.9.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 243. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What is the value of \(f(t)\) when \(t\) is 1? Enter integers only.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 5.9.2–5.9.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 81. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Function \(g\) gives the amount of a chemical in a person’s body, in milligrams, \(t\) hours since the patient took the drug. The equation \(g(t)=600\cdot (\frac35)^t\) defines this function.

    1. Which is the best choice for the domain of \(g\)?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.9.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(t\geq0\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Which is the best choice for the range of \(g\)?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.9.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(0 < g \leq 600\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 5.9.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Analyze a situation and determine whether it makes sense to connect the points on the graph that represents the situation.
  • Describe the relationship in a graph of an exponential function using function notation.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 5.9.1: Evaluating Expressions for Different Values of \(x\)
    • In this activity, you addressed a common confusion of mistaking the expression \(2^x\) for the expression \(x^2\).
  • 5.9.2: Analyze Underlying Relationship in a Graph of a Function 
    • In this activity, you were given a graph of a function, analyzed the underlying relationship, and described it using function notation.
  • 5.9.2: Self Check 
  • 5.9.3: Graph Equations to Solve Problems
    • In this activity, you graphed equations to solve problems and thought about appropriate values of their variables.
  • 5.9.3: Self Check 
  • 5.9.4: Deciding on Graphing Window 
    • In this activity, you were given an additional opportunity to apply what you know about key characteristics of an exponential function and used it to model real-world data.
  • 5.9.5: Interpret Graphs to Find Approximate Values
    • In this activity, you interpreted graphs to determine an approximate value of a function.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 5.9.6: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
